grapher 1.0
  • Get started
  • Reference

    Introduction to Grapher

    grapher.Rmd

    Overview

    Usage

    To create a grapher, instance, simply pass in one of the following: 1. An igraph object 2. An \(n \times n\) symmetric adjacency matrix 3. An \(n \times 2\) edgelist 4. A grapher configuration

    Given any of these types of inputs, grapher produces an interactive, WebGL-accelerated, D3v4 compatible, force-directed graph with some suitable default parameters.

    n_nodes <- 10L
G <- igraph::sample_grg(n_nodes, radius = 0.1)
grapher(G)

    grapher instances support method chaining via magrittr pipes. For example, to update the node colors, the updateNodeColor accepts a vector of hexadecimal RGB or RGBa values with the same length as the number of nodes:

    { light_red <- rgb(1, 0, 0, 0.5); light_green <- rgb(0, 1, 0, 0.5) }
node_colors <- rep(c(light_red, light_green), times = n_nodes/2)
grapher(G) %>% 
  updateNodeColor(color = node_colors)

    Edge colors are updated synonomously, although they do not support transparancy values.

    blue <- rgb(0, 0, 1)
edge_colors <- rep(blue, igraph::ecount(G))
grapher(G) %>% 
  updateNodeColor(color = node_colors) %>% 
  updateEdgeColor(color = edge_colors)

    Of course, the instance can also be saved and reused.

    g <- grapher(G)
g %>% removeNodes(node_ids = seq(5L))

    grapher is also fully shiny compatible
